												[8/10] - Just Add Water's console-to-PC port reawakens the 2005 Xbox release with better visuals, audio, and stability on the PC... for the most part. Stranger's Wrath is a fairly straight-forward action/adventure strategy game that introduces a unique gameplay mechanic where your ammo consists of tiny creatures each with a distinct ability to distract, devour, and destroy your enemies. The game allows you to seamlessly alternate between a third-person view for ease of mobility, and a first-person view for shooting the critters at foes and obstacles. Every level brings on a diverse challenge that can be approached differently each time and delivers enjoyable boss fights that can be demanding enough to make you rethink your strategy. The story is interesting and comical and introduces twists and turns that completely change the atmosphere of the game without going too far out into the bizzare. It IS an oddworld, after all.On the downside, Stranger's Wrath suffers from some aggravating glitches and performance flaws that remind you of the horrors that follow game ports. Issues such as loading errors, frame-rate drop, achievements not unlocking, textures missing, and incorrect subtitles are littered throughout the game. Stranger, the protagonist, has poor voice acting and every creature of the same species has the SAME voice-over which easily breaks the personality of the subservient characters, and diminishes the quality of the game itself. There is not much progression other than unlocking unique ammo and some minor upgrades. Most of the more interesting unlocks are not revealed until much later in the game, but at that point it really starts get a lot more exciting and fun.Overall, I found the game to be satisfying to the end. Playing on hard and attempting to capture the enemies alive rather than dead makes the game challenging, but not at all frustrating. With a little patience to tolerate the technical flaws, Stranger's Wrath can be a very enjoyable experience. Out of all the games included in the Oddbox anthology, this one is by far the best out of the four.

												Stranger's Wrath is a really mindblowing and innovating game. Being 11 years old it still hold gameplay and mechanics, that are solid to this day. This game was so far ahead of its time.As a player you will get a huge amount of content, a huge variety of ammo and loads of different ways to complete the levels. You play as a bounty hunter and you are equipped with a crossbow, that uses ammo in forms of critters that you hunt. That means you shoot down bad guys with spiders, fuzzles or even bats! You choose yourself how you will deploy this ammo, as they all has their own purpose; wrap them in web, deploy as a living mine or shoot a living skunk that makes the enemy throw up. The games really leaves you with a whole lot of choices. You even get to decide if you want to kill the bandits, or catch them alive for a bigger bounty.The enviroment is great and I don't usually like deserts, but I found this one fun and exciting. It was in no way empty. As the game progress you are taken from the desert to the forest, temples, jungles and even more places, so the scenery constantly changes, with a lot of lore and detail, which keeps the player constantly occupied. Together with a lot of content and challenges, this really wraps up a good experience. I found to have ZERO problems playing this game and had no crashes at all. I was even surprised of how well and good the control and camera were. I felt it was made for PC. I did experience only getting the 'Easy'-achievement, even though I finished it on 'Hard'. All other achivements worked and I am sure this is not a common thing. The Achievements are fun and interesting to complete. They are realistic, but hard, so I would recommend doing them. Fun and a good challenge.For people who played the previous Oddworld games: You are in for a treat! Even though Abe and Munch is far away and not present, the keen eye will spot references and items from RuptureFarms and such. Even some of the wildlife that lives in these parts, also exists in Abe's part of Oddworld. The two are woven good together and the old-school fan will surely feel some nostalgia when noticing those things. The story is as always extremely good and really reflects on things from our real world. The game has a great message that is delivered with an awesome storytelling and interesting gameplay.This game's mechanics and content easily beats todays big games. They have always been very creative, the guys behind these games. The game is also very re-playable, which games rarely are.9.5/10*Would have been 10 if the Hard-achievement had worked for me.

Teal DeerDevelopers: Oddworld Inhabitants Publishers: Oddworld Inhabitants Initial release: Dec 2010Genre: FPS, Action#Worth/NotWorth: #CautionAdvisedExposition, Concurrence and SummationWARNING: Contains live ammunitionOddworld: Strangers Wrath is quite a departure from the previous Oddworld games. No side scrolling or rescuing other inhabitants. Well, not in the same way at least. In Strangers Wrath, you play as a bounty hunter and for most intents and purposes his name is stranger. Early on it is established he desires a surgery (to live). It is left ambiguous why exactly. As a bounty hunter you have the ability to switch between first and third person camera views. In first person mode you have a crossbow; You have different sorts of ammunition used for various purposes. Some examples would be laying traps, stunning, doing heavy damage and immobilization. The thing is is that the ammunition is live. No no, actually alive. They are animals and insects you are firing. You even must hunt them yourself. Though you can buy them from the general store should you desire. Your base ammo, the one that is always there (as in infinite) is zapflies which also have the ability to charge if you hold (as in stop firing) for a bit. Which gives you the ability to always deal some damage as well as stun should you completely run out of ammo. Since you have a lot of options when it comes to ammo, you also have the ability to capture enemies alive as well as bounties. With the difference being more moolah (the actual name of the currency in game) To be spent at the store on ammo and more upgrades like faster regen for stamina, clip extenders and overall more stamina. Stranger is rather impervious to damage (relatively) he actually can die very easily however he can literally just shake and the damage is taken away. With the exchange being stamina; So it's important to keep track of. Now, the reason I don't outright recommend this game is after a narrative twist the game has a sudden difficulty spike I wasn't terribly fond of; suddenly favoring capturing enemies alive as the more effective option rather than the more difficult one with higher reward. Also your ammo bags have been reduced (if you got them) but now capturing enemies restores ammo. It's a weird switch that I don't think everyone will be okay with especially if you were really enjoying the game loop before the twist.THE GIST The HD retexture is much appreciated. The game looks and plays very smoothly. However the difficulty spike won't appease everyone. Much to my chagrin.Follow my curation for more

												In Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath, you will fill the boots of a strange, otherwise mysterious bounty hunter who tracks down villains and outlaws for "moolah" -- Wild West Wanted-Dead-or-Alive style. You'll explore a grand world of frontiers ranging from old Western towns, uninhabited wildernesses and some more modern type industrialized compounds. The game allows you to play in either third person or first person mode where third person view will be used mostly for exploration and first person mode for when it gets down to action and combat. The main character’s name is Stranger and he needs to raise money for a medical procedure he must undergo in order to survive. Stranger will go from town to town through forests and wildernesses, capturing outlaws and fighting his way through mob syndicates...all in the duty of the bounty assignments he receives from the local Bounty Store.The only weapon Stranger carries is a modified crossbow strapped to his forearm. This is a mean weapon and its ammunition is actual living creatures and critters which he harvests from the environment. There are plenty of it crawling and bouncing around. This unique ammunition is also upgraded as the game progresses through its various levels which in turn is a good thing, a very good thing, because crime bosses become extremely difficult to take down later in the game, especially on hard difficulty settings. Other in-game role-playing elements include amour storage upgrades and knuckle dusters.Doing bounty hunts might start to feel repetitive later on in the game and the pattern rather predictable, but the story takes a spin towards something different and totally unexpected. The story. That is essentially what distinguishes the guys at Oddworld Inhabitants from the rest. Their story telling technique. To me, personally, Oddworld's games are treasures. I first played Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee on PC back in 2000 and then later during 2006 I played Stranger's Wrath (maiden release) for the first time on console. The upgraded port of Stranger's Wrath, namely the HD version was first announced in 2010 for release on PC and PlayStation 3, developed by Just Add Water and is one of the more distinctive games released from the "old" generation. It's entertaining and fun, story rich, beautiful in HD and demonstrates the passion and love you get from the Oddworld Universe. I'm Odd... I recommend this game!

												After the apparent shortcomings of Munch's Oddesy, the Oddworld crew wisely decided to invest in creating a new hero for the franchise, something that was fresh and fit well into the 3D scene. Abe never felt like he fit in with a 3D platformer and with Munch being tied to Abe... Stranger was a good alternative to explore Oddworld in a 3D envrioment. It was a risk; and one that payed off in aces. It introduces gameplay mechanics and an immersive story that devs struggle, more often then not, fail in leaps to pull off today. You hunt your bounties with live ammo and it's up to you to decide how to do it, or If you want to chuck the bounties in the slammer or get rid of them for good. The more useful ammo, such as bolimites, fuzzles and chipmunks come up quite freqnetly and is often high in the ammo department, while some of the more damaging creatures are rare. The game does push you towards getting the enemies alive through the abundant ammo of that nature and higher payout, but it's also often a lot harder for that route. Which makes two distinct playstyles and either way, you need to get creative. Bosses are often tough, and require good knowledge of your ammo in order to capture them alive. With the game itself out of the way, lets talk about the port.Many people have seen issues with performance, on my 7970, it runs well and I've never seen a problem. BUT. you need to check if it will run. there are some demanding features, such as grass, which will have in game implications if you're forced to disable them as you might not have any idea you can hide over there for example. The achievements in this game are also borked. they will not save progress if you quit. that is to say, you will bounty 250 bad guys and you won't get rewarded for it unless you either play the game for long enough to get it; or you save and farm quick loads so you can bounty one or two idiots over and over.

												One of my favorite games of all time. An incredible amount of love and thought went into this, and it's immediately apparent. The originality, humor, gameplay, and meaningful undertones all come together to form an unforgettable experience.This game is simply... fun(ny). You can listen in on the hilarious dialogue of any character, laugh at the attention-♥♥♥♥♥ chipmunk farting on your crossbow and being "allergic to your ugliness", lose yourself in Michael Bross' amazing soundtrack, appreciate the truly unique design and setting, punch complacent chickens in the face and steal their money, notice the parallels between harmonious peoples being subverted by industrialism and a people out of allignment with nature; the list goes on. The gameplay is intense and both 1st and 3rd-person views are fluid and change seamlessly. The animal-ammo system is as awesome as it is funny, with each animal serving a specific purpose so you have a lot of options on how you defeat your enemies.Being an Oddworld game, the humor is what you'd expect... It's ♥♥♥♥in' hilarious! There's a lot of unabashed humor and when you really listen to lots of characters, things get funnier. I've never laughed so much from somebody saying "I like oatmeal" before. Oddworld's humor always makes me happy, and games that make you laugh this much are doing something very right! It's just so entertaining.Is it original? Well just look at a few screenshots of the game and you'll see there isn't anything out there like it. The characters are interesting, and Stranger (the one you play as) is pretty badass. The environments and music combine to create an other-worldy feel, different yet similar to the previous games, but still of it's own. Originality is an Oddworld staple.The story is good, but I don't want to reveal anything so I'll just say it has heavy environmental undertones. It's in no way preachy, but the connections between native peoples being killed off by a more powerful and "civilized" culture is definitely there, and it makes you think. This is a fictionized example of a very real and re-occuring issue in humanity. To me this is the icing on the cake, because not only is this a great game but it promotes a more positive and sustainable direction for humanity; living in harmony with nature and not against it. Since this game has so much sentimental value to me, I don't see many downsides, but other people might. If you're not invested in the story or experience then you might feel the gameplay style gets repetitive, but I think if you invest yourself in it, you'll find more than enough to keep you entertained throughout the game. Just pay attention to some of the aspects of the game mentioned above and hopefully you love it! It doesn't have much replay value unless you find each playthrough a novel and enjoyable experience. You're some weird like guy that looks like no one else around, the major towns are filled with chicken people (they are really annyoing and have very cliche lines), there are weird native people that are like 2 feet tall, and then there are the bad guys which basically are all the same looking.It's cheesy, weird, annoying at times, but somehow still fun. Instead using conventional ammunition, you collect "live ammunition". Small animals that you capture which carry a range of different effects from provoking an enemy to a more convenient location, to blowing them to smithereens.Overall it's a great game which is too often brushed over, and easily worth your time should you have cash to spare.

												I cautiously recommend this game.It's obviously a very big departure from previous games in the series. No followers to rescue, no puzzles to solve, instead it's a surprisingly successful mix of FPS combat and third person action. Luckily I got sick of saving up and Googled it, but I can't even imagine how frustrating it would be to save up for two thirds of the game, skipping many useful upgrades, only to find out that it was pointless.This is such an obvious design flaw, I don't know how they left it in the game.

Not a review of the port itself. I was very fortunate in being able to have a rig which supported a smooth port experience. However, there were still occasional visual glitches and the game crashed every time after I died during the last few segments of the game. So even at its best performance the game runs only adequately.I wish I could say I enjoyed this game more. The most creative aspect of the game is using the creature ammos to capture or kill enemies. This dead or alive bounty hunting mechanic is the core of the gameplay, but it barely gets developed upon after its introduced, and what's worse is that they ditch several mechanics after the halfway point of the game. The game can be played in the 3rd as well 1st person perspective, but all the 3rd person perspective is for is very basic 3rd person platforming and combat, as well as traversing the levels faster. The game has a currency which the plot informs the player is very important, motivating the player to capture more enemies than they kill. This makes for interesting gameplay, as it takes longer and is more risky to capture enemies alive than it is to kill them, but alive enemies pay out more. The earlier levels are also built around a combination of stealth and cover, which combined with the creative crossbow tools, gives the play options in how to complete a level. There are also upgrades and ammo to buy, giving you more to do with your money.Without spoiling anything, about half-way through the game money stops mattering, your upgrades stop mattering and capturing enemies alive doesn't really make a difference anymore. This is a problem as multiple of the player's tools is built around distracting and stunning enemies as well as killing them. The dead or alive element goes out the window, and the game becomes a very generic console fps, complete with parking garage level design. It feels like the game ran short of time or budget and lost everything which made the game unique as a fps.Overall the game is enjoyable but bland. I would ultimately say that the game is average, but since I can only recommend or not recommend a game, I can't really recommend an average game when there are already so many good to excellent games to play on steam, especially in this genre. For Oddworld fans I would say its worth at least a single playthrough, just so you can have experienced another aspect of the Oddworld universe. As a fan of the first two games on the playstation I was dissapointed that not as much of the same atmosphere was found in this game, although that might be a consequence of the xbox graphics still not being able to provide the same amount of detail as the prerendered environments of Oddysee and Exoddus.FPS fans can pass on this game, but Oddworld fans should see this game through at least once. That's assuming of course they can get this port to work, since it is infamously unstable. Otherwise skip this port and find it on the original xbox.

Posted: March 25, 2016
												Rating: 7/10Overview: Third/First Person Action AdventureThe Good:+ The game certainly is original in terms of its character, world and story. + Game controls between first and third person and does a great job switching between the two. Third person is mostly used for traversing the environments while first person is used for the crossbow to kill/capture enemies. + The premise is simple, but nicely executed. You collect a bounty and then proceed to go hunt it down, usually with a lot of enemies and obstacles along the way. The game is linear and you can only hunt one bounty at a time but each bounty is unique in its own way.+ Each bounty is unique, like a mini boss battle, each one requires special tactics. You can either kill or capture the enemies. Killing enemies is easier but nets you less money while capturing them is the opposite.+ Use money to upgrade your character+ Unique ammo, your crossbow can hold two types of ammo at one time. The Average:Graphically the game is decent, it certainly isn't ugly but nothing really stands out. The story while decent feels like it never meets its potential. It's hard to care about the main character, villains or anybody else. The Bad- Broken Achievements, exiting the game makes you lose your achievement progress. - I really hated the voice acting. - Game crashes after every death and load in the second half of the game. A reoccurring problem for many users with no fix in sight, making the game almost unplayable. I solution is to quit the game before you die and continue from the main menu. Conclusion:For some reason this game reminds of me of a Rare game back in the day. Animals that talk with cute fuzzy ammo to collect. A fun game with some serious technical issues that should be fixed. Given the age of the game its surprisingly holds up pretty decently.

												Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively. Gameplay: This was not my first time playing this game; in fact, this is my sixth time playing through the game, counting the five playthroughs I had of the Xbox version (also the game really can't do the "Only on Xbox" claim anymore, so that's kinda funny). I took a couple of years off from this game, since it was one of my yearly playthrough games, and coming back to it with both a new perspective and a new control scheme, this game is still as fresh as ever. It's a blend of FPS, stealth, and platforming that just works when it honestly shouldn't.The FPS elements can be very tactical in nature, with your main weapon being a crossbow that can hold two of nine available ammo types; each one having their own specific uses. You'll soon find the three or four that work for you and forget the rest, but again, that's not to say that they're useless. There does seem to be mouse smoothing and auto-aiming in this game, which can be distracting for some, but I never found it to be that big of a deal. They can be disabled, as far as I know. This game does have replenishing health, but it's different from how a Call of Duty game does it. You have a health and a stamina gague; the stamina gauge is replenished by either taking in enemies or standing still. Sprinting doesn't drain stamina, but it doesn't replenish it, either. You also use stamina to heal yourself, with a full stamina bar often recovering about 75% of your total health. There's a great deal of tactics to healing, with the choice oftentimes being made between ducking behind a wall or stunning everyone guns-a-blazing.Of course, another option is to stealth your way around areas, especially if there happens to be a very dense crowd of enemies. It's still recommended that you bag enemies, though, and it's all your choice how you tackle the areas. Your punch, if you've been upgrading it through the store, will most often knock out enemies in one hit. Goons and bosses have their own health and stamina gagues as well. Obviously, an alive baddie is worth more than a dead baddie, so do try to take 'em in alive. It is possible to take in every boss alive (some are pretty hard to do, though) with the exception of very late game bosses, but the stakes have changed at that point, and that's all I'll say on that.All in all, I didn't really have any issues with any of the areas, with the possible exception of the last bit before the final boss fight being one helluva difficulty spike. It's something that I can guarantee is different from anything you've played before, and even after six playthroughs, the game still feels fresh and juicy as ever. 10/10.Story: Man, this game has some great dialogue. It's easy to spend a while in towns just listening to what the Clakkerz have to say. The Grubs have some pretty great lines as well. Basically, there's a lot of lines in this game that'll almost assuredly get a laugh out of you if you even have a remotely crude sense of humor. The surprising bit is that the storyline actually gets good about 2/3 of the way through. That's not to say that the first 2/3 of the story are worth losing; it's just that the stakes become that much higher at that point. The ending is unexpectedly dramatic and actually really good. For a lot of great laughs and a surprisingly well-written story, I give the story a 9/10.Graphics: As expected from an HD port, the game looks great. One thing that I'm glad to have seen toned down from the Xbox version is the utterly absurd amount of bloom. Seriously, the amount of bloom in the Xbox version far surpassed any premise of artistic direction. Speaking of, the art direction of this game is absolutely fantastic; as to be expected from an Oddworld Inhabitants game. It's an excellent mix of high-tech gadgets and old-timey western aesthetics. The characters, enemies, ammo, areas... just everything looks fantastic. The technical aspects... aren't so fantastic. For starters, the game uses SSAA, which is HORRENDOUSLY inefficient. The game itself isn't too demanding, but the really weird part is that the game prefers my Integrated Graphics on my i5-3470. I could only really run it on 4x SSAA because of this (and yes, I did try and go through NVIDIA Control Panel; it didn't change anything). Even despite the not-so-great technical side of this game, the game still looks fantastic enough for me to give this game a 4/5 for graphics.Sound: Well, the music is pretty good. I always make the note as to whether or not I'd bring this along with me on my MP3 player, and I wouldn't really do that for this soundtrack, but there are some very good songs in there that fit the "odd" vibe this game is trying to pull. Voiceacting is great, with a lot of the humor coming from just the inflections that the voiceactors use. Again, it's hilarious how the Grubs seem to be speaking in all-caps. A rather disappointing aspect of the voiceacting, however, is that the voice clips are rather low-fidelity. I don't have the greatest audio equipment in the world (a Gamecom 777 headset into the included USB sound card) and I can hear the compression on the voice clips. It makes me sad. Surely they could've sourced some uncompressed master audio files or something? Because of this, I can't give the audio portion of the game a perfect, but I still feel alright giving it a 4/5.Overall scores are 10/9/4/4; 9.0/10. Despite not being the best coded port of all time, the gameplay is still very much worth your time and money.

												Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively. Gameplay: This was not my first time playing this game; in fact, this is my sixth time playing through the game, counting the five playthroughs I had of the Xbox version (also the game really can't do the "Only on Xbox" claim anymore, so that's kinda funny). I took a couple of years off from this game, since it was one of my yearly playthrough games, and coming back to it with both a new perspective and a new control scheme, this game is still as fresh as ever. It's a blend of FPS, stealth, and platforming that just works when it honestly shouldn't.The FPS elements can be very tactical in nature, with your main weapon being a crossbow that can hold two of nine available ammo types; each one having their own specific uses. You'll soon find the three or four that work for you and forget the rest, but again, that's not to say that they're useless. There does seem to be mouse smoothing and auto-aiming in this game, which can be distracting for some, but I never found it to be that big of a deal. They can be disabled, as far as I know. This game does have replenishing health, but it's different from how a Call of Duty game does it. You have a health and a stamina gague; the stamina gauge is replenished by either taking in enemies or standing still. Sprinting doesn't drain stamina, but it doesn't replenish it, either. You also use stamina to heal yourself, with a full stamina bar often recovering about 75% of your total health. There's a great deal of tactics to healing, with the choice oftentimes being made between ducking behind a wall or stunning everyone guns-a-blazing.Of course, another option is to stealth your way around areas, especially if there happens to be a very dense crowd of enemies. It's still recommended that you bag enemies, though, and it's all your choice how you tackle the areas. Your punch, if you've been upgrading it through the store, will most often knock out enemies in one hit. Goons and bosses have their own health and stamina gagues as well. Obviously, an alive baddie is worth more than a dead baddie, so do try to take 'em in alive. It is possible to take in every boss alive (some are pretty hard to do, though) with the exception of very late game bosses, but the stakes have changed at that point, and that's all I'll say on that.All in all, I didn't really have any issues with any of the areas, with the possible exception of the last bit before the final boss fight being one helluva difficulty spike. It's something that I can guarantee is different from anything you've played before, and even after six playthroughs, the game still feels fresh and juicy as ever. 10/10.Story: Man, this game has some great dialogue. It's easy to spend a while in towns just listening to what the Clakkerz have to say. The Grubs have some pretty great lines as well. Basically, there's a lot of lines in this game that'll almost assuredly get a laugh out of you if you even have a remotely crude sense of humor. The surprising bit is that the storyline actually gets good about 2/3 of the way through. That's not to say that the first 2/3 of the story are worth losing; it's just that the stakes become that much higher at that point. The ending is unexpectedly dramatic and actually really good. For a lot of great laughs and a surprisingly well-written story, I give the story a 9/10.Graphics: As expected from an HD port, the game looks great. One thing that I'm glad to have seen toned down from the Xbox version is the utterly absurd amount of bloom. Seriously, the amount of bloom in the Xbox version far surpassed any premise of artistic direction. Speaking of, the art direction of this game is absolutely fantastic; as to be expected from an Oddworld Inhabitants game. It's an excellent mix of high-tech gadgets and old-timey western aesthetics. The characters, enemies, ammo, areas... just everything looks fantastic. The technical aspects... aren't so fantastic. For starters, the game uses SSAA, which is HORRENDOUSLY inefficient. The game itself isn't too demanding, but the really weird part is that the game prefers my Integrated Graphics on my i5-3470. I could only really run it on 4x SSAA because of this (and yes, I did try and go through NVIDIA Control Panel; it didn't change anything). Even despite the not-so-great technical side of this game, the game still looks fantastic enough for me to give this game a 4/5 for graphics.Sound: Well, the music is pretty good. I always make the note as to whether or not I'd bring this along with me on my MP3 player, and I wouldn't really do that for this soundtrack, but there are some very good songs in there that fit the "odd" vibe this game is trying to pull. Voiceacting is great, with a lot of the humor coming from just the inflections that the voiceactors use. Again, it's hilarious how the Grubs seem to be speaking in all-caps. A rather disappointing aspect of the voiceacting, however, is that the voice clips are rather low-fidelity. I don't have the greatest audio equipment in the world (a Gamecom 777 headset into the included USB sound card) and I can hear the compression on the voice clips. It makes me sad. Surely they could've sourced some uncompressed master audio files or something? Because of this, I can't give the audio portion of the game a perfect, but I still feel alright giving it a 4/5.Overall scores are 10/9/4/4; 9.0/10. Despite not being the best coded port of all time, the gameplay is still very much worth your time and money.
